Dictionary.Name: The Free On-line Dictionary of Computing (27 SEP 03)

Definition.WordDefinition:
kit
<jargon> ({Usenet}, possibly from {DEC}) Slang for a full software distribution, as opposed to a {patch} or upgrade. A source software distribution that has been packaged in such a way that it can (theoretically) be unpacked and installed according to a series of steps using only standard {Unix} tools, and entirely documented by some reasonable chain of references from the top-level {README file}. The more general term {distribution} may imply that special tools or more stringent conditions on the host environment are required.
[{Jargon File}]
(1994-11-18)

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Kit \Kit\, (k[i^]t), v. t. [imp. {Kitte}.] To cut. [Obs.] --Chaucer. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Kit \Kit\, n. [See {Kitten}.] A kitten. [1913 Webster]
{Kit fox} (Zo["o]l.), a small burrowing fox ({Vulpes velox}), inhabiting the region of the Rocky Mountains. It is brownish gray, reddish on the breast and flanks, and white below. Called also {swift fox}. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Kit \Kit\, n. [Gf. AS. cytere harp, L. cithara. Cf. {Guitar}.] A small violin. ``A dancing master's kit.'' --Grew. [1913 Webster]
Prince Turveydrop then tinkled the strings of his kit with his fingers, and the young ladies stood up to dance. --Dickens. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Kit \Kit\, n. [Cf. D. kit a large bottle, OD. kitte beaker, decanter.] 1. A large bottle. [1913 Webster]
2. A wooden tub or pail, smaller at the top than at the bottom; as, a kit of butter, or of mackerel. --Wright. [1913 Webster]
3. A straw or rush basket for fish; also, any kind of basket. [Prov. Eng.] --Halliwell. [1913 Webster]
4. A box for working implements. [1913 Webster]
5. Hence: A collection of tools or other objects to be used for a specific purpose, often contained in a box which may be carried conveniently; a working outfit, as of a workman, a soldier, and the like; as, a plumber's kit; a doctor's kit; a cosmetic kit; a first-aid kit. [1913 Webster +PJC]
6. A group of separate parts, things, or individuals; -- used with whole, and generally contemptuously; as, the whole kit of them; the whole kit and kaboodle. [1913 Webster +PJC]

kit n. [Usenet; poss. fr. {DEC} slang for a full software distribution, as opposed to a patch or upgrade] A source software distribution that has been packaged in such a way that it can (theoretically) be unpacked and installed according to a series of steps using only standard Unix tools, and entirely documented by some reasonable chain of references from the top-level {README file}. The more general term {distribution} may imply that special tools or more stringent conditions on the host environment are required.

Dictionary.Name: Virtual Entity of Relevant Acronyms (Version 1.9, June 2002)

Definition.WordDefinition: KIT Kernel software for Intelligent Terminals (T-Online, Telekom, BTX)

kit n 1: a case for containing a set of articles 2: gear consisting of a set of articles or tools for a specified purpose [syn: {outfit}] 3: young of any of various fur-bearing animals; "a fox kit" v : supply with a set of articles or tools [syn: {kit out}, {kit up}]
